comments.commentBody: I cannot believe that Roger lost. I am so disappointed! It it time that Roger retire? I thought that this article was witty: http://www.forbes.com/sites/bluecarreon/2011/06/30/alternative-careers-f...

What's with all the anti-Djokovic comments? Arrogant? Glib? Yikes -- the guy is great! He's a great tennis player, he's intelligent -- listen to some of his interviews -- he's multilingual, he's a UNICEF ambassador, and he's funny. Maybe his humor just goes over your heads?
And did I mention he's a great tennis player? Not only great shots, but what fortitude, and strength, and heart to come back and win that match as he did. Ajde Nole!

Response to Post 18: (1) One can assume that the NY Times would not mount a blog like this without elementary controls in place to prevent multiple voting. Even my little local newspaper can do that. To say that Henin is succeeding only because of improper multiple voting is ignorant and slanderous. Her success is because there are more people who understand tennis and who appreciate what a gift to tennis Henin was who are taking part. The point at issue is which player, at full health and rest and at the top of their game, would prevail head to head. I stated my reasons in post #6: Henin on clay and hard courts, perhaps Steffi on grass. Henin wins.  (2) What is this in your blog about" Henin had the best two handed backhand, that is all." Are you conducting a serious discussion or just messing around?  (3) Some one else spoke of Steffi hitting flat and with power off of her backhand. I saw many of her matches and never saw that once. I repeat that Steffi's backhand was attackable and that is exactly how Henin would beat her. (4) Someone else belittled Henin at the net. Wrong, she had the speed and the racket control and was excellent at the net, far better than Steffi. Pound Steffi's backhand, then into the net is how Henin would win.  (5) I am heartened by how many in this poll recognize and appreciate Henin's ability, which was truly rare and a thing of beauty. To our loss she pushed herself hard, very hard, and wore herself out, many times during the competitive season and finally to the point that she had to retire. Her achievement came from her hard hard work, but that was also the cause of failures in her body. The disrespect shown in many of these postings flows more from the fact that she was shy, not good copy for the press and the PR guys, a very boyish body and mainly appreciated by people who have played competitive tennis at some level and appreciate what they were seeing when she played. Henin.
Back on top.
and talking about "arrogant" and "glib" go to usopen.org and listen to/read the after match interviews of Djokovic and Federer and then tell us who's lacking in class. . . sheesh.

Serena is a great tennis player deserving of great respect for her athletic prowess. She is also an international sports icon, not just an American one by virtue of her tennis accomplishments which I wholeheartedly accept. But embrace her. What does that mean? You only embrace people that you like apart from their achievements. And Serena unlike her sister has never displayed a likalble public personality. Should we embrace Trump with his pompous personality because of his wealth? Personality counts for something. Federer is embraced worldwide because of his gracious personality, and charming manner, Venus has become more popular over the years for the same reason. Serena's personality still needs work if she's to be embraced.

But frankly, I don't think that she cares whether she's embraced or not, just like McEnroe, Lendl, and Connors, didn't care during their careers. As Jimmy Connors once said, "It's not a popularity contest".

This pairing is, I think, a complete toss-up.  The voting seems to reflect the usual historical amnesia, so I voted for Sampras.  If Laver in his prime were in this mix, I'd be voting consistently for him...

Will someone ask Dick Enberg to stop referring to Rafa as "Na-DOLL" ? Johnnie Mac can show him how to pronounce it correctly. And if Nadal prevails on Monday and wants to say a few words in Spanish, I hope Enberg will agree, even if it takes away time from the Lexus commercial. Enberg has done a great job over the years and deserves go out on a high note.
@Ivan #31: Federer has class (most of the time), but his fans do not. Take a look at any tennis message board or join RF.com to see what I mean.

I think another problem they have is that I have heard from my nieces that a lot of the college kids use their parents and grandparents accounts to download films and share the info with their friends, so Netflix has a lot of people that are freeloading on the downloading side of things.....

Paul Myerberg is a god--a god with incredible endurance. I've never seen anything like today's blog. This is a tour de force. I kept checking back in even on games I was watching because his on-the-fly insights were so provocative and accurate. Wonderful!
And if Henin were to play Henin, well, not even Henin could beat her.  Meanwhile, in the real world, Serena is in the finals, again, twelve years after her first one. Hard to top that..
Dave Stewart as an agent?  I didn't know that agents were allowed to have real class.  Poor Dodgers, with such terrible "ownership."

Hogwash. Lee continues to lag behind Kershaw in most major statistics, including ERA (now a full run behind, Ks, H/9, innings pitched, wins, losses). Factor in the fact that Kershaw has only one less complete game than Lee, and that the former has a less reliable offense and bullpen to work with, it appears clear that Lee's ONLY claim to the Cy Young award this year would have to be made via either WHIP or shutouts, neither of which are sufficient.

Despite the fact that he has yet to demonstrate that he can win the games that really matter, Lee is an outstanding pitcher. There is a remote chance that he will have a more impressive resume at the end of the season than Kershaw, but the evidence is simply not present at this point that he deserves the Cy Young.

Lee is a fine pitcher having a great season.

The ML and NL record (post 1900) for ShO by a lefty is 11 by Koufax in 1963. The AL record for a lefty is 9 by Ron Guidry in 1978, and Babe Ruth in 1916.

I really DO wish these fellows who cover the Yanks would abandon the 'People Magazine' nonsense and permit this limited space to be used to consider the final weeks of the season and the chances the Yanks have of getting into and beyond the first round.  Yes, A-Rod has a bad thumb; get over it.  We won a higher percentage of  games while he was recovering from surgery than we had when he was in the lineup.  And how wonderful it will be when Mariano passes Hoffman.  Oh, and how are the Girardi children enjoying the weather...Look, we're in LA for a second night and, as of the sixth inning, we again have TWO HITS.  Yes, Weaver and Haren are good.  But this is ridiculous, for we were not better against Baltimore pitching that is below mediocre.  Teixeira praised Montero for taking full swings and, unlike nervous rookies, not retreating to a 'safe' mode of just getting balls out of the infield.  Hey, Mark -- do us a favor: If the choice is between watching you strike out again or watching you get a 'bingle' through the infield, we'll take the latter!  This team is NOT up to its own record of wins and losses.  It is streaky, self-indulgent, sometimes amateurishly managed and, in bush league fashion, inclined to make a mountain out of mole-hill accomplishments.  As for contributors to this column who keep reminding all of us that the Yanks are in first place, GIVE ME A BREAK.  The Sox have gone south for a while but will return with a SURGE.  I worry that, by the time Girardi wakes up to what's going on, we'll be looking at third place.  Stay tuned...

P.S.  Mathis has just made it 5-0 and the evening of embarrassment has but two at-bats to go.  There is something truly strange about this team.  From top to bottom, the batting order features fearsome slugging percentages and prodigious run production.  But each player is remarkable sub-par with the exception of Cano.  The DH spot has been useless, particularly with Jorge failing to find the fountain of youth.  The pitching has been surprisingly good, only to be frustrated by hitters who either bat down the walls or create surges of air.  As of now, of all teams in all divisions and with winning percentages of .550 or higher, I'd be more confident facing the Yanks.  They tend to be lousy in the early innings of any game, catching up with so-so relievers enter the game.  I doubt they'll ever get to see Philly pitching but, if they do, don't wait around for game 5.

Having been raised by a police offer, I understand the difficulty of an effective police force in India.  It is highly corrupt and ineffective.  As long as the politiciansm judiciary and police are corrupt, no laws or any changes will bring safety to common citizens who are struggling to raise a family and put food on the table.  Police need a living wage and support from government to be effective in combating crime and terrorism.  Educated are apathetic to the plight of poor and uninformed majority busy making their riches.  People like Anna are needed to bring awareness and mobilize the majority to keep the pressure and make any meaningful changes.  We need a revolution like Anna has initiated to raise the masses to hold politicians accountable and pay a severe price for their inactions at the ballot boxes.

Congratulations to NYT.  Thanks for this overdue effort!  India and India's aspirations are vital for the United States.  I hope that the news coverage of India will become broader and more in-depth with time and live up to the best practices in journalism to inform and educate masses.  Rather than focusing and just serving the American interests, I hope that this branded resource will serve the larger good by connecting cultures, business and politics and look at India for what it's and help make this world a better place for our future generations.

Only mildly amusing.
Ever spent any time in "The Pit" at the Delhi Airport?
I did.
Twice, while traveling to and from Kathmandu last November, with hundreds of other travelers from a variety of countries trying to connect home, sleeping on the floors without boarding passes or access to gates.
Upstairs, a beautiful, polished terminal with empty high-end shops, policed by clowns in uniform carrying automatic weapons.
Everyone is treated either as an enemy or disregarded completely, but no one can access a gate area without a boarding pass, which is issued a few minutes before departure through some vague goofball protocol.
Our passports were taken from us by a local Indian (who claimed he was an American Airlines employee in charge of security), who disappeared for over an hour, before finally returning with my passport and boarding pass.
My reward for complaining was to have my business class ticket replaced with the middle seat in the very last row of a 777, with no food for 15 hours to Chicago.
It was also somewhat humorous when officials paraded that flight's sky marshals in front of all passengers in pre-boarding for everyone to identify...
It was then I realized that India and her comedic circus of mis-management and corruption can be no real competition to the US economy.

Mr.Sahani correctly pointed out three important elements deliberately discarded by indian fed.govt.1.30%of the elected parlimentarians are with CRIMINAL records so deliberately interfering in any efforts to improve indian internal security.2.Not integrating in an effective reproducible manner the INDIAN PANCHAYAT COUNCILs at village level to federal police&home security which alone will be a good effective counterterror monitor&pre-empter.3.Lack of initiative at the secondary school level to implement preventive,nationalistic integration oriented PROGRAMMES to prepare future INFORMED INDIANS. I do also agree with Mr.Sahani the prevailing APATHY across the sections of indian community the INDIFFERENCE to violence,death&destruction,ownership&responsibility.There are lots of PREACHERS but NOT ENOUGH PRACTITIONERS in INDIA to alleviate this MALADY.

I was looking at the interactive map "Where Were You on September 11, 2001?". From that you can see that outside of US and Europe, India has the largest number of readers. So I think this is a good move by the times. Good luck.

when a nation continues to commit error, it is not unusual to expect terror.
terrorism is a complex phenomena. just simply talking about a war on terror won't work. one has to execute and deliver. certainly something seriously wrong at the thinking and planning and execution level. the govt. and the home minister has lot to do. hope they come out of complacency, inefficiency and be more insightful in handling the issue.
i feel sorry that my country, aspiring to be a global super power is not doing the home work right.
the old and out dated thinkers, ...if they can not think new age, they must leave things to the young .
the old is always not gold.
what the govt. needs is a bold thinking and action to do away with terrorism.
lest india will continue to suffer ...i bet.

I agree with others who say that Mrs. Gandhi is entitled to some degree of privacy, but not entirely.  As the leader of her party, at a minimum, she has an obligation to other party members to inform them about her health, so that they can determine if party adjustments need to be made.  Furthermore, her desire to avoid all public scrutiny can be acceptable in a non-democratic nation, but not in India.  With her attempt to appoint her son as the next PM, despite his inability to garner votes, no notable record in Parliament, and his absence during the recent protests against corruption - is democracy in India simply ceremonial, while real power is based on the old Indian formula of family connections?

We have worked with the Tibetan community in exlie in India for over 10 years. TibetanPhotoProject dot com

In that 10 years, we have had the good fortune of visiting India and have come to love this amazing and complex country.

We are very excited over this NY Times effort and look forward to its evolution. If there is one piece of advice we would give. The West does not hold any answers for India. India is doing fine in its own evolution in these very exciting times.
